column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Matussek (Germany): Germany welcomes\r
#Text=\r
#Text=this year's Security Council debate on women and\r
#Text=\r
#Text=peace and security, marking the eighth anniversary of\r
#Text=\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=Germany associates itself with\r
#Text=\r
#Text=the statement made by the French presidency of the\r
#Text=\r
#Text=European Union and would like to add the following\r
#Text=remarks.
#Text=We welcome the particular emphasis of this\r
#Text=year's debate on the issue of women's equal\r
#Text=participation and full involvement in all efforts for the\r
#Text=maintenance and promotion of peace and security.
#Text=Resolution 1325 (2000) has given us a very clear\r
#Text=mandate in that regard.
#Text=Unfortunately, as today's\r
#Text=debate and the report of the Secretary-General\r
#Text=(S/2008/622) have shown, many structural and\r
#Text=institutional impediments remain.
#Text=We call upon the\r
#Text=United Nations system and upon ourselves, the\r
#Text=Member States, to step up our efforts leading to\r
#Text=concrete advancement in the equal inclusion of women\r
#Text=in peace talks, justice processes and peacekeeping.
#Text=Let me emphasize that Germany firmly believes\r
#Text=that the creation of a strong and effective United\r
#Text=Nations gender entity has to be part of those efforts.
#Text=We hope that the Secretariat will soon provide the\r
#Text=membership with the requested detailed paper on\r
#Text=modalities, so that substantive action can be taken\r
#Text=before the end of the current session of the General\r
#Text=Assembly.
#Text=Resolution 1325 (2000) and the Secretary-\r
#Text=General's report rightly emphasize the essential role of\r
#Text=training United Nations staff, peacekeeping personnel\r
#Text=and civil society as a means of ensuring the equal\r
#Text=participation of women.
#Text=Let me therefore highlight\r
#Text=some best practices and some examples of how\r
#Text=Germany actively contributes to the effective\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) in the field\r
#Text=of training.
#Text=The Centre for International Peace Operations\r
#Text=was established by the German Federal Government in\r
#Text=June 2002 with the aim of enhancing Germany's\r
#Text=civilian capacity for crisis prevention.
#Text=The Centre's\r
#Text=core mandate is the training, recruitment and support of\r
#Text=German civilian personnel for peace operations and\r
#Text=election observation missions, conducted in particular\r
#Text=by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in\r
#Text=Europe, the European Union (EU) and the United\r
#Text=Nations.
#Text=The Centre cooperates closely with\r
#Text=international and other European training centres, such\r
#Text=\r
#Text=as the Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training\r
#Text=Centre in Ghana, and is a founding member of the EU\r
#Text=Group on Training.
#Text=Gender aspects, in particular the\r
#Text=role of women in conflict resolution, are consistently\r
#Text=taken into account in the design of training modules.
#Text=Overall, since 2002, a total of 416 women from\r
#Text=Germany and 129 women from abroad have\r
#Text=participated in the Centre's training courses.
#Text=In 2007,\r
#Text=52 per cent of participants in such training courses\r
#Text=were women.
#Text=The German Government also funds a pilot\r
#Text=project called the Mobile Peace Academy OMNIBUS\r
#Text=That "bus line" has since toured several\r
#Text=countries in the northern and southern Caucasus\r
#Text=regions.
#Text=On each of its stops, it has conducted train-\r
#Text=the-trainer sessions with local non-governmental\r
#Text=organizations, public officials, teachers and journalists\r
#Text=on the relevance of resolution 1325 (2000) and on the\r
#Text=integration of a gender perspective into their work for\r
#Text=peace in the region.
#Text=Just last week, the bus returned to\r
#Text=Berlin and was greeted with a high-profile press\r
#Text=conference.
#Text=The adoption in June this year of resolution 1820\r
#Text=(2008) on women and peace and security and sexual\r
#Text=violence in armed conflict was a landmark\r
#Text=achievement.
#Text=It strengthened and further developed our\r
#Text=commitment to the protection of women in situations\r
#Text=of conflict and their active participation in the\r
#Text=promotion of peace and security.
#Text=Resolution 1820\r
#Text=(2008) created many new obligations for the United\r
#Text=Nations, for the Security Council and for Member\r
#Text=States.
#Text=Inter alia, the Secretariat was asked to submit a\r
#Text=comprehensive and operational report on the\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1820 (2008) by June\r
#Text=I am pleased to announce today that Germany has\r
#Text=decided to provide the necessary funds for the\r
#Text=recruitment of an additional policy specialist in the\r
#Text=Peacekeeping Best Practices Section of the Department\r
#Text=of Peacekeeping Operations, whose task it will be to\r
#Text=oversee coordination of that report.
#Text=In addition, he or\r
#Text=she will be tasked with designing a global strategy for\r
#Text=the implementation of resolution 1820 (2008) and with\r
#Text=developing and elaborating key training messages and\r
#Text=an outreach and partnership strategy, including with\r
#Text=troop- and police-contributing countries.
#Text=We are confident that Germany's financial\r
#Text=contribution will significantly facilitate the submission\r
#Text=of a report that will be substantive and operational and\r
#Text=will allow us to further develop the vision of resolution\r
#Text=We take that contribution as proof that\r
#Text=Germany, as a friend of resolution 1325 (2000), is\r
#Text=deeply committed to the vision of both landmark\r
#Text=resolutions, 1325 (2000) and 1820 (2008), and will\r
#Text=continue to undertake concrete efforts for their\r
#Text=implementation.
